segments.text: I see the woman’s dress and apron, and I can’t believe she hasn’t noticed the water yet.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: Her clothes are probably soaked, but she’s just standing there, drying dishes like nothing’s wrong.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I think she’s going to slip any second, but she doesn’t even seem to realize it.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The children are right behind her, and she has no idea what they’re up to.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I wonder if she’s ever been this oblivious before or if this is a first.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The puddle is getting bigger, and it’s going to spread all over the kitchen, but she doesn’t care.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I can’t believe how careless she’s being, especially with the kids right there.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The dish towel is bunched up in her hands, and she’s just focused on that one plate.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I think she’s in her own little world, and nothing is going to snap her out of it.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The whole scene is like watching a slow-motion disaster, and she’s the only one who doesn’t see it.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I can’t help but feel a little sorry for her when she finally realizes what’s happening.
segments.speaker: PAR
